title: Learn

Learn
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
See @knuth84 for additional discussion of literate programming.

title: Careers
text:
Careers
In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

title: Welcome to R Programming!
text:
The next 5 computing sessions are going to introduce you to R programming. This is a computer language very commonly used in Life Sciences to do statistical analyses and interpret large data sets.
Don’t worry if you’ve never done any programming before - we’re starting from the very beginning.


Advances in Life Sciences has let to the creation of terrabytes of Big Data. We can now sequence millions of bases of DNA, calculate expression levels of thousands of proteins and track the movements of whales around the world.
In order to be able to make sense of these large datasets, we use programming languages. It would be quite difficult to calculate a statistically significant result if your dataset has more than 1000 values!



Below is a table of a recent publication for each subject which used R in the analysis - quite varied!

Life Science R Programming Examples. Images from Google and Adobe Stock







Degree
Paper title
Icon




Biomedical Science
Pediatric leukemia and maternal occupational exposure to anticancer drugs: the Japan Environment and Children’s Study



Biochemistry
The ORP9-ORP11 dimer promotes sphingomyelin synthesis



Biological Science
Humpback whale song complexity and evolution on a northwestern Pacific breeding ground: Okinawa, Japan



Pharmacology
Explaining Blood–Brain Barrier Permeability of Small Molecules by Integrated Analysis of Different Transport Mechanisms



Forensic Science
An Open-Source Implementation of the CMPS Algorithm for Assessing Similarity of Bullets







This course is your first introduction to R.
Next year (Level 5), most of you will continue R programming in Research Methods and Skills. Forensic Science students will use other Statistical Analysis software.
In your final year (Level 6) you will all do a research project - this may be in the lab, a literature review or data project. R programming can be used for analysis of your research data in all of these projects.
Biological Science (Molecular Biology) and Biochemistry students will also do a Python-programming module at Level 6. This builds on what you know from R.



First get yourself set up with R and RStudio - click the “Set Up” tab for instructions.
Next start the classes under the “Learn” tab. This is all of the material for the five sessions - you can work through them at your own pace.
Each page will cover a new concept, or have an activity on for you to try. As you work through, try to experiment - change parts of the code examples and see if it will still work. This is how you figure out how it works.
If you have any other questions, grab a member of teaching staff in the session or email Dr Lizzie Wadsworth at L.Wadsworth@kingston.ac.uk



GIF of Homer Simpson at a Computer

title: Set up
text:
Set up
We are going to use RStudio for this course. You can do this on campus from a University Computer, online using a free Posit Cloud account that you can access from any web browser, or by downloading R and RStudio onto your own device.
Click below to see the set up instructions for each:

University ComputerOnline CloudOwn Device


To get set up, follow the below steps. Click each step for detailed instructions.






Step 1: Launch RStudio from AppsAnywhere






Type in AppsAnywhere to the windows bar. This will open in a web browser
Type in RStudio in AppsAnywhere
Click “Launch” and wait for it to install and open.




GIF of Opening RStudio











Step 2: Navigate to your OneDrive folder






Copy and paste the following into the Console on the left, and press enter.

setwd("O:/")

Click the “More” cog and select “Go To Working Directory”

You should now be in your OneDrive. You should be able to recognise the files and folders listed, from what you have saved here in your other classes.



GIF of Opening OneDrive








If you get the error message ‘cannot change working directory’





Occasionally there is an issue with how OneDrive is loaded on the University computer.
If you get the error message:
Error in setwd("O:/") : cannot change working directory
Then try the following. Replace the underscores with your K number.
setwd("C:/Users/K______/")
Click the “More” cog and select “Go To Working Directory”
Then find and click on the folder:
OneDrive Kingston University
Click the more cog and select Set As Working Directory



GIF of Opening OneDrive with common error














Step 3: Create or move to a folder for LS4003





If you don’t already have a folder for LS4003 Statistics, then you can create one by clicking “New Folder” and entering a name.
If your new folder doesn’t appear, click the refresh button (to the right of the more cog).
Then:

Click into your new folder
Click the More Cog and select “Set As Working Directory”




GIF of Making a Folder











Step 4: Create an R file





Once you’re in your folder you can create and save an R file. This is where you put your code.

Click on the Green Plus icon and select “R Script”
In the top bar, click “File” and then “Save”
Give your file a name (e.g. “R_tutorial_1” )

When you make any changes, you can save the file by going File -> Save.
You can also save by holding down Control and S at the same time.



GIF of Making an R File








Note





This will automatically add the “.R” extension so we know it’s an R file - R_tutorial_1.R









Warning





Make sure you can find your file in file explorer. Always back up your work such as saving in OneDrive or emailing to yourself so that you don’t lose your progress.












Step 5: Write and run R code





You’re now ready to run some R code!

Copy and paste the following into your R file:


value <- "Hello World"
value


Highlight both lines and click the “Run” icon (green arrow)

You should see a result in your console (bottom left panel) and your environment (top right panel)
You’re now ready to start learning R!



GIF of Running an R File







Posit Cloud is a free online browser version, allowing you to work from any device.






Caution





You shouldn’t need a paid account for this course. If you use up the compute hours then I suggest downloading RStudio and R onto your own device.



To get set up, follow the instructions below:






Step 1: Launch RStudio from AppsAnywhere






Create a free account and login
Create Project -> RStudio
Name your project (where it says “Untitled Project”)




GIF of Creating a PositCloud Project











Step 2: Create an R file





Once you’re in your project you can create and save an R file. This is where you put your code.

Click on the Green Plus icon and select “R Script”
Click the Save icon
Give your file a name (e.g. “My_R_file” )

Remember to keep saving your file using the save icon.



GIF of Making an R File








Note





This will automatically add the “.R” extension so we know it’s an R file - My_R_file.R












Step 3: Write and run R code





You’re now ready to run some R code!

Copy and paste the following into your R file:


value <- "Hello World"
value


Save your R file by clicking the save icon
Highlight both lines and click the “Run” icon (green arrow)

You should see a result in your console (bottom left panel) and your environment (top right panel)
You’re now ready to start learning R!



GIF of Running an R File







If you’re working on your own laptop or computer it’s also possible to download and run R and RStudio. These are both free, open-source programs.






Note





If you’re working on a tablet, chromebook or your device is typically slow, I recommend looking at the Posit Online Cloud option instead



Installing R and RStudio can be a bit fiddley - let the teaching team know if you’d like any support.
Why two programs? R is the programming language, that takes our code and creates our graphs. RStudio is a program we use to edit and view our R files and plots; known as an Integrated Development Environment (IDE).






Step 1: Install R





You can Install R from this website. You want to select the version for your operating system (Windows or Mac).









Step 2: Install RStudio





Once R is installed, you can install RStudio from this website.
The free version is more than sufficient I don’t know anyone who has needed Desktop pro.









Step 3: Create or move to a folder for LS4003





Once RStudio is open, you want to browse files until you can find your documents - wherever you keep your university files.
Next, create a folder to keep all your R programming work in (e.g “LS4003 R Programming”).
Click on the new folder to enter it. Click the cog, and “Set as Working Directory”









Step 4: Create an R file





Once you’re in your project you can create and save an R file. This is where you put your code.

Click on the Green Plus icon and select “R Script”
Click the Save icon
Give your file a name (e.g. “My_R_file” )

Remember to keep saving your file using the save icon.



GIF of Making an R File








Note





This will automatically add the “.R” extension so we know it’s an R file - My_R_file.R












Step 5: Write and run R code





You’re now ready to run some R code!

Copy and paste the following into your R file:


value <- "Hello World"
value


Save your R file by clicking the save icon
Highlight both lines and click the “Run” icon (green arrow)

You should see a result in your console (bottom left panel) and your environment (top right panel)
You’re now ready to start learning R!

title: Set up
text:
Follow the Quick Start for your tool of choice to get a simple website up and running. After covering the basics, read on to learn about website navigation and other more advanced website features.
